results.title: R.D. Laing's Glasgow
results.creator_credit: John McGreevy, Pat Ferns, Nielsen-Ferns and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cities”.
R.D. Laing discusses the city of Glasgow - “its commerce, industry, learning and people; its violence and tenderness and great warm-heartedness”.

results.title: R.A.N. ashore and afloat: it's the navy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cinesound Review”.
Special 1000th issue of Cinesound Review devoted to the Royal Australian Navy; the Senior Service. Class room training and recruitment is put to good use aboard the H.M.A.S. Latrobe. Photography by Geoffrey Thompson.

results.title: R.A.A.F. Newsreel. No. 13. The Queen and the R.A.A.F
results.creator_credit: H Rayner and Australia. Royal Australian Air Force. Directorate of Public Relations
results.brief_description: Screen magazine: Commemorates the important part played by the R.A.A.F. during the visit of Her Majesty the Queen and His Royal Highness, the Duke of Edinburgh to Australia, February 1963. Providing air transport in an R.A.A.F. Convair; immaculate guards of honour; exhibitions of precise formation flying and performance by the R.A.A.F. Central Band.

results.title: R. O'Hara Burke
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Behind the Legend”.
Presents a dramatized reenactment of the events surrounding Robert O’Hara Burke through the memories of his friends. Aspects of his life, the Burke and Wills Expedition and his death are reconstructed. Introduced by Manning Clark and written by Thomas Keneally. Cast includes Tony Allyn as Burke, Cornelia Frances, Ian Nimmo, Richard Lupina, Don Philps, David Williams, Clive Marshall and Shirley Sunners.

results.brief_description:
A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival.
This work features a group of rollerbladers displaying their moves, their falls and the tricks of their trade.

results.title: Quintessence: five short films by Barry J. Hershey
results.creator_credit: Waldon Woods Film and Barry J Hersey
results.brief_description: This meditative exploration by filmmaker Barry J. Hersey presents life in a visual poetry. Themes of life, birth, death and spirit fill each piece. Form and substance are explored. Reality and art are questioned as we journey through the spiritually observant eyes of the filmmaker. Each piece reveals the different and crucial aspects of the human condition and the place or insignificance of a person on earth. The nature and contours of the landscape are seen through new eyes while the suggestive ocean offers deeper interpretations of the world around us. The filmmaker makes use of the effects that music has on the visual experience with dreamy and relaxing sounds unifying the meditative aspects of this style of filmmaking.

results.title: Quilts in women's lives
results.creator_credit: New Day Films and Pat Ferrero
results.brief_description: A multi-award winning film on the traditional art of quiltmaking and its affect on the lives of seven women. Each from quite diverse backgrounds, the women discuss the influences that inspire quilt design, and how their lives and times are depicted in their work.
results.description: A multi-award winning film on the traditional art of quiltmaking and its affect on the lives of seven women. Each from quite diverse backgrounds, the women discuss the influences that inspire quilt design, and how their lives and times are depicted in their work.

results.title: Quills
results.creator_credit: Fox Searchlight Pictures, Hollywood Partners, Industry Entertainment, Walrus and Associates, Julia Chasma, Peter Kaufman, Nick Wechsler and Philip Kaufman
results.brief_description: Paris, 1804 - following the bloody climate of the French Revolution erotic writer, the Marquis de Sade, resides in the Charenton Asylum for the insane where he continues to pen his sadomasochistic literature. When his latest tome upsets Napoleon, Dr Royer-Collard (Michael Caine) is despatched to ensure that de Sade be published no more. In charge of the asylum is a benevolent priest Coulmier (Joaquin Phoenix) who allows de Sade’s writings as a form of therapy. Coulmier and Royer-Collard soon come into conflict about the treatment of the Marquis and the running of the asylum. But the priest faces a greater challenge - his lust for a common laundress sparks suppressed desires, but it is she who is sneaking out the Marquis’ incendiary prose. Meanwhile the doctor marries a virginal bride, brought up in a nunnery, who he mercilessly abuses. Philip Kaufman (The Unbearable lightness of being, Henry and June, The Right stuff) presents the Marquis de Sade as a mostly harmless presence (ignoring his historical squalidity) - compared to the enshrined corruption within the Church. Kaufman ably captures the fetid environs of the asylum; the barely contained carnal desires of the inmates, their depravity and insanity, inflaming the nightmarish atmosphere of these scenes. Rush puts in an impressive, if manic, performance as a tormented artist, whose prose may inspire acts of passion and murder witnessed throughout the film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fox Searchlight Pictures, Hollywood Partners, Industry Entertainment, Walrus and Associates, Julia Chasma, Peter Kaufman, Nick Wechsler and Philip Kaufman
